project1.title: Patient Tracker
project1.alt: Home page of the Dinosaur Patient Tracker app
project1.description: This application tracks patients at a pet dinosaur veterinary clinic. This project showcases the Vanilla Javascript and additional tools we learned during the first part, the Foundations milestone, in our front-end bootcamp program at the Nashville Software School.
project1.briefDescription: Check out this patient-tracking app for the most RAWRsome vet clinic around. This project showcases the Vanilla Javascript we learned during our Foundations milestone.
project1.background: This project helped solidify my knowledge of several tools and technologies, such as CSS Flexbox, Bootstrap accordions, modals, and forms, jQuery event listeners, additional Javascript methods, and FontAwesome for making logo and button icons more visually appealing.
project1.technologiesUsed: Bootstrap, CSS, FontAwesome, Github, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery

project2.title: Compete
project2.description: This app allows the park rangers in Alaska's Katmai National Park to track brown bear feeding behavior during salmon season in July and August, keep a record of the bears' attempts and successes catching fish, and quickly identify the winners.
project2.briefDescription: Want to track statistics and see the winners? Compete is your app! It allows park rangers to track brown bear feeding behavior, keep a record of attempts and succeses, and identify the winners. This project is an exploration into using ES6 modules. Bear-y nice!
project2.background: This project was an opportunity to practice the ES6 Modules file structure, continue to expand our Javascript and jQuery skills, and writing getter and setter methods for retrieving and updating data.
project2.technologiesUsed: Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, Github, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery

project3.title: Sundew Smoozer
project3.alt: Messaging app with a sundew flower theme
project3.description: Sundew Smoozer is a messaging application. Users can select a user profile, add a message to the conversation, and delete one of their own messages. The userâ€™s message gets validated to make sure it includes content; otherwise, the user is prompted with a popup informing him that he needs to add a message to send one. Additional options include clearing all messages, changing the site color theme to a dark mode, and enlarging the font size.
project3.briefDescription: Message with your friends! Peruse their conversation and see what you've missed! Delete a message if you inadvertantly sent it! Sundew Smoozer is a messaging application that gives you these tools. Users can select a user profile, add a message to the conversation, and delete one of their own messages.
project3.background: This group project was an opportunity to hone our skills of working together in the same codebase, follow ES6 Modules file structure, introduce SCSS extensions in our code, use jQuery more extensively, and standardize our code by starting to follow ESLint rules. My contributions to this project included adding a new message by typing in text and pressing the Enter key, validating the message, the ability to change the color theme, and  the ability to clear all current messages with a click, making messages responsive, and ensuring that users can delete only the messages they wrote.
project3.technologiesUsed: Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Github, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery, moment.js, SASS, Webpack

project4.title: Foodies Unite
project4.alt: Pinterest-like app with a food theme
project4.description: This project is an exploration into using a Firebase database for user authentication and data management. It is a site similar to a much simplified version of Pinterest, and it includes meal recommendations for various places around the US and the world.
project4.briefDescription: This is my version of Pinterest, and it's all about food! It includes delicious meal recommendations for various places around the US and the world.
project4.background: This project gave me the opportunity to start using Firebase for data management, Google authentication, and deployment, make Promises and learn how to explain the story of such Axios calls, really grasp the relationship between the code in different component and data folders, learn how to debug with a whole new level of complexity and attention to detail, better understand the nuances of getting and setting data, better comprehend the relationship between data collections through ERDs, and so much more - it has been exciting to delve in at the beginning of each phase of this project and slowly emerge with new knowledge, tips, and tricks each time.
project4.technologiesUsed: Axios API, Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Firebase, Github, Google login authentication, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery, JSON, JSONLint, Lucidchart, moment.js, moqups, Sass, Webpack

project5.title: Travel Diary
project5.description: The Travel Diary app is an online journal that allows users to keep track of destinations on their bucket list and then capture diary entries when they actually get to visit these sites.
project5.briefDescription: Most of us love to travel - near or far, there are always thoughts we want to capture and reminisce about later on. The Travel Diary app allows you to keep track of destinations you want to visit and easily capture your impressions once there.
project5.background: This project was a great opportunity to keep practicing my skills manipulating data across multiple collections in a Firebase database. It helped me improve my ability to outline the logic and code for getting data from multiple collections; it also helped me get even more comfortable with various CSS components as well as Javascript and jQuery elements.
project5.technologiesUsed: Axios API, Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Firebase, Github, Google login authentication, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery, JSON, JSONLint, Lucidchart, Sass, Webpack

project6.title: Nautilus Explorer
project6.alt: Drawing of the Nautilus submarin interior
project6.description: This application is a dashboard for the captain and crew of the Nautilus Explorer, allowing them to keep track of the vessel's crew members, destinations, as well as species and environmental data identified during their journey. This group project gave us the opportunity to practice and enhance our understanding of CRUD processes.
project6.briefDescription: Welcome aboard! Join Captain Nemo and his crew as they journey to destinations across the world in order to conduct progressive scientific research.
project6.background: In this group project, I was responsible for the user authentication code, CRUD features on the Destinations collection, and the CSS for the Dashoard and the page template. It was fun trying out new CSS styling options - such as the overlaid text on the Dashboard page and the typewriter effect for the page headers. As a team, we got even better at project planning and code management. Personally, I learned how to debug better, became better at explaining the code, and improved my understanding of elements such as forms.
project6.technologiesUsed: Axios API, Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Firebase, FontAwesome, FreeLogoDesign, Github, Google login authentication, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery, JSON, JSONLint, Lucidchart, moment.js, moqups, Sass, Webpack

project7.title: Renaissance Faire
project7.alt: Screenshot of the Renaissance Faire site
project7.description: This app allows the owners of a company that organizes Renaissance Fairs across the country to see the status of their fairs. They are able to see the food products, souvenirs, staff, and shows available at each fair as well as review graphs and details of the costs of each type of service provided.
project7.briefDescription: Calling all knights and dames, Renaissance Faire time is upon us! If you want the most impressive "carouse" in your town, be sure to engage the services of this Renaissance Faire planning business. "Prithee, sit you down and have a laugh!"
project7.background: This group project gave us the opportunity to better understand how to work with promises and use Axios calls to manipulate data in multiple collections simultaneously. We also got to practice our pair programming skills and proved to be a great group of communicators who shared progress, debugged together, and ensured no one was left behind. My individual contributions included completing CRUD functions on multiple collections, adding a new page for viewing an event's details, filtering event data by price range, and figuring out the big function that displayed all the event data simultaneously.
project7.technologiesUsed: Axios API, Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Firebase, Github, Google login authentication, HTML5, JavaScript, jQuery, JSON, JSONLint, Lucidchart, Sass, Webpack

project8.title: A Mushroom Picker's Adventures
project8.alt: Screenshot of the Mushroom Picker app
project8.description: This was our first venture into React. Our Mushroom-Picker project was intended to give us the opportunity to familiarize ourselves with using state and props in React, understand how data gets transferred across files, and learn how to manipulate the display in the component files.
project8.briefDescription: We're going mushroom picking! Our first venture using React, this app allows you to fill your basket with random mushrooms from the forest. However, surprises lie ahead! Find out what happens when you choose a deadly, poisonous, or a magic mushroom!
project8.background: From really starting to grasp the concepts of state and props to learning how to pass data into individual components and how to make updates as well as how to control CSS based on React component attributes to having more fun with CSS in order to meet the project requirements for highlighting the deadly mushroom selection and the full basket scenarios, this project gave me the opportunity to both learn new concepts and practice current skills.
project8.technologiesUsed: Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Github, HTML5, JavaScript, React, Sweetalert2, Webpack

project9.title: Front-End CAPSTONE
project9.technologiesUsed: Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Github, HTML5, JavaScript, React, Sweetalert2, Webpack

project10.title: Back-End CAPSTONE
project10.technologiesUsed: Bootstrap, CSS, ES6 Modules, ESLint, Github, HTML5, JavaScript, React, Sweetalert2, Webpack
